abstract.p: In the context of globalization, individuals have an increased chance of being infected by multiple viruses simultaneously, thereby highlighting the importance of developing multiplexed devices. In addition to sufficient sensitivity and rapid response, multi-virus sensing techniques are expected to offer additional advantages including high throughput, one-time sampling for parallel analysis, and full automation with data visualization. In this paper, we review the optical, electrochemical, and mechanical platforms that enable multi-virus biosensing. The working mechanisms of each platform, including the detection principle, transducer configuration, bio-interface design, and detected signals, are reviewed. The advantages and limitations, as well as the challenges in implementing various detection strategies in real-life scenarios, were evaluated. Future perspectives on multiplexed biosensing techniques are critically discussed. Earlier access to multi-virus biosensors will efficiently serve for immediate pandemic control, such as in emerging SARS-CoV-2 and monkeypox cases.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the context of deep globalization, novel and unknown viruses can spread rapidly worldwide, thereby causing the public to be infected by multiple viruses simultaneously and resulting in major damage to public health and global economics [1]. It has also been proven that co-infection with more than one virus in an individual has a higher risk of severity and even mortality [2,3]. This is especially the case for highly contagious or deadly viruses where few effective medicines or vaccines are available, such as the continuously evolving human coronavirus (HCoV), emerging monkeypox virus, henipavirus, and Ebola [4].

Due to their high sensitivity and selectivity, polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based assays are currently regarded as the gold standard for viral disease diagnosis. However, PCR is dependent on expensive equipment and complex sample preparation before nucleic acid amplification; on the contrary, biosensors can provide direct testing, fast response, and high versatility to be adopted for different viruses. Despite being highly challenging, effective and versatile biosensing techniques are urgently needed to develop multi-virus detection under current circumstances, particularly while considering the crucial role of controlling the spread of viruses in protecting public health.

A typical multi-virus biosensor consists of a viral receptor, transducer, signal detector, signal processor, and displayer. Biosensors can be categorized as optical, mechanical, or electrochemical according to the transducers and response signals. Bioreceptors recognize viruses or variants of interest using specific probes such as enzymes, antibodies, and nucleic acids [5]. Thus far, bioreceptors have served as a key component in achieving high selectivity. Proper design of the bio-interface can also greatly enhance the binding efficiency, and consequently, the sensitivity. Signals can be received by detectors to generate different types of response signals, as illustrated in Fig. 1 . Alternatively, biosensors can integrate multiple functions to maximize detection performance [6]. For the past few decades, biosensors for single virus detection and viral disease diagnosis have been comprehensively reviewed [7,8]. There has been a review paper on monitoring multiple cardiovascular disease markers [9]. Immunosensors for label-free multiplexed influenza viruses have also recently been reviewed [10]. However, to date, a comprehensive review focusing on multiplexed virus-sensing techniques is still lacking. Therefore, this review aims to systematically elaborate on state-of-the-art approaches and achievements in multi-virus biosensing technologies and discuss its future perspectives. We review optical, electrochemical, and mechanical multi-virus biosensors for application in real-life settings. The transducer and system design, technique for realizing multiplexed detection, biofunctionalization strategies, and advantages and challenges of each technique are systematically discussed. In Section 2, we introduce optical biosensors for multi-virus detection including plasmonic, dielectric, colorimetric, and fluorescent biosensors. Section 3 discusses electrochemical multi-virus biosensors. These include field-effect transistor (FET)-, amperometric-, impedimetric-, and electrochemiluminescence (ECL)-based devices. In Section 4, mechanical biosensors containing microcantilever- and piezoelectric-based multi-virus biosensors are reviewed. At the end of each section, we have assessed the advantages and limitations of the corresponding biosensing platform. Section 5 introduces the surface functionalization strategies for multi-virus biosensors. Section 6 discusses the challenges and future perspectives for designing next-generation multi-virus biosensing platforms. Special attention was given to critically comparing the strategic differences in designing biosensing systems for clinical use regarding single-virus, multi-virus, and multi-biomarker detection. Finally, Section 7 presents the conclusions of this study.

sec.title: Optical biosensors for multi-virus detection
sec.p: Optical biosensors can perform multi-virus detection in various formats, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Optical biosensors can be plasmonic active metal- or dielectric-based biosensors. They can detect changes in the refractive index (RI) or biolayer thickness in a label-free manner and report the response signal in the wavelength shift, intensity, or pattern change. With advances in nanofabrication techniques, as well as lab-on-fiber [11] and lab-on-chip platforms [12], versatile and sophisticated metasurface-based biosensors can be designed to precisely control the light field for various biosensing applications [13]. In contrast, label-based optical biosensors make use of different signal probes to distinguish between multiple target viruses. Fluorescence-based biosensors detect fluorescence signals generated by chemical reactions in reagents. Colorimetric biosensors distinguish the liquid color/intensity using various probes specific to different target viruses.

sec.title: Plasmonic-based biosensors for multi-virus detection
sec.p: Plasmonic-based optical biosensors are gaining popularity owing to their fast response, high accuracy, and ability to perform label-free diagnosis. Surface plasmon resonance (SPR), localized SPR (LSPR), surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS), and colorimetric plasmonic assay-based biosensors have been widely studied for point-of-care (POC) multi-virus testing. This section focuses on the first three types of multi-virus detection, while the last type is discussed in more detail in Section 2.3.

sec.title: SPR-based biosensors
sec.p: A surface plasma wave is formed when a solid surface with free charge is excited by incident light, and the basic mechanisms of SPR have been fully discussed in previous studies [14,15]. For biosensing applications, the SPR response signal can be the incidence angle or intensity change and can be detected using a spectrometer, characteristic charge-coupled device (CCD), or complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) imaging.

SPR biosensors can detect multiple viral markers simultaneously by dividing one sensor die into several individual regions of interest (ROI) and then functionalizing the active ROIs with corresponding bioreceptors [[15], [16], [17], [18]]. Thus, a single biochip can detect thousands of viral targets simultaneously based on imaging scanning technology known as SPR imaging [17,19]. Based on this, the reflected light is coupled into a CCD or CMOS camera, and the detection pixel on the sensor chip can be fabricated at the micrometer scale to obtain an ultrahigh throughput [18,19]. Real-time virus monitoring in aerosol has been achieved based on SPR biosensor [20]. Viral aerosol samples were generated by commercial nebulizer, with the sample flow rate of 15 μL min−1. The portable sensing platform achieved 6 × 10 PFU mL and 7× 10 pfu mL detection limit for MS2 bacteriophage and influenza A H11N9 virus respectively. Herein, regarding biofunctionalization, antibodies can be immobilized on-chip as a mixed solution to achieve multi-virus detection, but such schemes showed remarkably reduced sensitivity compared to sequential immobilization of antibodies one-by-one.

SPR can be integrated with photonic crystal (PhC) fibers, achieving impressive sensitivity up to 12000 nm per refractive index unit (nm RIU−1). The authors concluded that the proposed SPR configuration has the potential for unknown multi-analyte analysis within the 1.33–1.40 RI range, including viral samples [21].

SPR devices have been commercialized for single biomolecule detection [22], but their dependence on couplers and temperature controllers makes them challenging for POC testing. In addition, the effect of the uniformity of the plasmonic metal on sensitivity remains to be further studied. Research on building multifunctional SPR biochips for multi-virus detection is urgently needed to eliminate the dependence on multi-channel instruments for multiplexed detection.

sec.title: LSPR-based biosensors
sec.p: LSPR occurs when light is incident on plasmonic active metal nanoparticles (MNPs) or nanopatterned metal thin film with working structure dimensions much smaller than the light wavelength [23]. A strong electric field is triggered in the vicinity of the metal surface, which significantly enhances the light-matter interaction in the near field. Furthermore, nano structured LSPR biosensors allow the 3D binding of viruses with the working metal with increased binding density.

Quantitative detection of different viral markers is important. A Au triangular nanoprism (AuTNPs)-based biosensor was recently proposed for label-free detection of SARS-CoV-2 antigens, nucleic acids, and antibodies [24]. AuTNPs were fixed at the bottom of a 96-well plate, followed by AuTNP functionalization to capture different targets (Fig. 2 A). Spectrum resonance shifts characterized the presence of target molecules. The platform detects multiple targets using a single instrumentation run with extraordinary sensitivity (89–977 aM for different viral targets) and selectivity (>96%), providing a configuration example for multi-virus detection. LSPR technology can also be used for viral gene analysis, as shown in a recent study that detected four dengue viruses with high sensitivity and selectivity [25]. This biosensor allowed us to investigate the genetic similarity between viruses by analyzing the recurrence relation matrix. Considering that the nature of respiratory viruses is continuously evolving and the goal is to prevent other epidemics caused by unknown viruses, the ability to quickly analyze and predict virus species is especially important.

In general, LSPR biosensors offer shorter electromagnetic field decay length, smaller sensing volume [26,27] and are highly versatile owning to the high tunability of nanoparticles. The particle size of MNPs in an LSPR biosensor is close to the size of the target analyte, leading to a faster binding process [14]. It is worth mentioning that the performance of a LSPR biosensor is highly dependent on the working structure (geometries, dimensions, materials etc.) [23,28], and spatially matching the target virus particles with the hotspot (strongest electric field) is crucial in achieving optimal sensitivity [29].

sec.title: SERS-based biosensors
sec.p: When the target virus is trapped near rough plasmonic active metal nanoparticles or thin-film surfaces, the Raman scattering signal can be remarkably enhanced [30], enabling the detection of viruses at low concentrations [31]. To date, considerable progress has been made in the commercialization of SERS platforms for multi-virus detection [32].

A common multiplexed detection approach in solution is to distinguish the Raman signals of different viral targets by adopting different Raman tags. Neng et al. fabricated silica-encapsulated SERS nanotags and specific antibody-conjugated magnetic nanoparticles for the simultaneous detection of multiple viral antigens. The authors create “fingerprint” for each virus by adjusting the Raman dye concentration inside the silica shell, and the presence of different viral proteins can be distinguished by the Raman shift with similar intensity [33]. The sensor achieved a high log linear detection range (10 pg mL−1 to 10 ng mL−1) with a 10 pg mL−1 LOD level for three viral antigens.

The combination of SERS and lateral flow assay (LAF) allows for simple operation and fast response for at-home applications. Multiplexed detection can be achieved by simply including different lines or points in an assay on the SERS tag. A lateral flow strip with a micro-detection array was recently proposed for the detection of 11 respiratory viruses, as illustrated in Fig. 2B [34]. Bimetallic nanoparticles covered with Nile blue A and methylene blue were fabricated. The target viruses were captured using on-chip probes when the samples flowed through the detection spots. The target viruses were characterized by the intensity of their response signals to generate 11 different response signals. A similar approach was adopted for the simultaneous detection of the influenza A H1N1 virus and human adenovirus. Novel dual-layer Raman dye molecule-conjugated Fe3O4@Ag magnetic tags were modified with antibodies for high selectivity recognition [35]. Importantly, the combination of SERS and LAF for multiplexed virus detection can help distinguish diseases with similar clinical features, providing early stage at-home diagnosis [36].

sec.title: Dielectric-based biosensors
sec.p: The high absorption of metallic materials leads to a large heating effect in plasmonic biosensors, which has become a major concern. Therefore, dielectric materials with a high Q-factor, low heating effect, and low susceptibility to electrochemical interference have attracted significant interest. Optical biosensors based on dielectric materials can be designed in various structures (such as nano-waveguides and resonators) to achieve a high Q-factor and small mode volume, thus enhancing the light-matter interaction.

sec.title: Bilayer interferometric biosensors
sec.p: Interferometric biosensors with bilayer configurations reflect light from different material interface interferences, and the interference pattern/light intensity changes due to viral target binding [10,[37], [38], [39]]. They are simple and robust for label-free detection [10]. An interferometric reflectance imaging sensor (IRIS)-based biosensor can perform multiplexed detection of thousands of microspots using optical imaging devices [40]. The working principle of IRIS has been introduced in detail in previous studies [41].

Si substrates/SiO2 layer IRIS chips functionalized by receptor (antibody/nucleic acid) microarrays have been widely reported for multi-virus detection [39,[42], [43], [44]]. Recently, a single-particle IRIS multiplex viral sensing platform has been proposed [45]. The study started with a comprehensive comparison of the three chip functionalization methods (Fig. 2C (a)), namely (I) antibody functionalization, (II) antibody functionalization after DNA modification, and (III) pre-mixing of antibody–DNA conjugates and viral samples. The authors demonstrated that by pre-mixing the antibody–DNA conjugates with the virus specimen, on-chip antibody immobilization is no longer required, and the test can be achieved in one homogeneous step. Subsequently, specific DNA probes for Ebola, Marburg, and Lassa viruses were immobilized on commercial IRIS chips. The three recombinant vesicular stomatitis viruses, mixed with their specific antibody–DNA conjugates, were flowed onto the sensor chip in microfluidic cartridges (Fig. 2C (b) and (c)), and a CCD camera was used to record the response reflectance imaging signals. This study validates the importance of bio-interface design for achieving good detection performance.

sec.title: Photonic crystal-based biosensors
sec.p: A PhC comprises periodically distributed materials and structures with different relative permittivities. PhC biosensors are highly flexible and compact in structure. In previous studies, PhC-based biosensors coupled with SPR [46], microcavity [47], and resonator [48] have been used for detecting different viruses. The sensor can be designed to be compact by integrating it into a microfluidic system. For example, a recent study proposed an eight-channel ring-resonator photonic integrated circuit biosensor for six viral antigen detections [48]. Antibodies for each target virus were used to functionalize the resonator sensors, and microfluidic channel was adopted for buffer delivery. A resonance shift can be observed after antibody captured target virus and the signal threshold was 5 pm.

With the development of lab-on-fiber platforms, PhC fibers have emerged in the field of biosensor design for virus detection owing to their compact structure, high versatility, and tunability [[49], [50], [51]]. In addition, they are highly compatible with commercial multiplexed detectors [51].

sec.title: Colorimetric biosensors
sec.p: In a colorimetric multiplexed platform, different viruses can be recognized by the difference in liquid color, and a library of viral types, concentrations, and liquid colors can be built [52]. The change in liquid color is caused by plasmonic active nanoparticles [53], pH-active particles [54] or biological molecular techniques [55]. Combined with the lateral flow assay, a colorimetric biosensor can be used for low-cost detection of influenza virus [56].

A compact half-automated biosensing platform was proposed for POC testing of respiratory viral samples (antigens and antibodies) in clinical scenarios [57]. Horseradish peroxidase was used to modify the detection antibodies to react with tetramethylbenzidine. Response color intensity of each detection spot was analyzed using a half-automated portable optoelectronic analyzer. To obtain quantitative results, the light intensity was proportional to the virus concentration. The sensitivity and selectivity met the World Health Organization criteria for POC SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis.

Different plasmonic active metals can be merged into one detection matrix, and multi-virus detection is performed by distinguishing the color signals. Liu et al. modified gold/silver nanoparticles and magnetic beads by using receptors and capture probes. Each nanoparticle has its own light extinction property. The concentration of each nanoparticle in the solution can be changed by first adding the target virus and then applying a magnetic field to remove target-bonded magnetic beads [53]. As such, the remaining nanoparticles in the reagent govern the solution color, as determined by a UV-VIS absorption spectrometer within 90 min. Subsequently, the system detected each virus using a picomolar reagent by analyzing the shift in the absorption spectrum, achieving LODs of 9 pM and 15 pM for hepatitis A virus and hepatitis B virus respectively. Therefore, it would be of great interest to build a virus-solution color library for recognizing various viruses.

sec.title: Fluorescence biosensors
sec.p: Fluorescence biosensors detect biomolecules via fluorescence quenching, fluorescence enhancement, or resonance energy transfer [58]. Fluorescence-based sensing has been adopted for multiplexed viral gene detection using loop-mediated isothermal amplification [59,60] and cascade amplification [61]. Efforts are ongoing to study novel fluorescent probes for ultrasensitive detection of HIV/HCV DNA markers [61].

The ability to perform a one-step diagnosis with a small sample size and fast response is crucial for both on-site and at-home detection. In a recent study, an imaging array was proposed for the label-free detection of different avian influenza viral DNA [62]. A black plate containing detection spots, 6 mm in diameter, was used for signal monitoring. The result (grey scale) can be analyzed on a mobile phone instead of a spectrometer, thereby empowering on-site and POC scenarios. The platform provided 129 pM–141 pM of LOD level in detecting three avian influenza viruses. Multiplexed detection is achieved by distinguishing signals from different locations on the detection plate.

Clustered regularly spaced short palindromic repeat (CRISPR)-based detection has been adopted for one-tube multiplexed viral-genes detection [63] and has achieved high gene recognition selectivity and provided naked-eye signals. The detection limit reached 100 RNA copies/reaction in 25 μL sample. To avoid signal overlapping and to enhance sensitivity, Tian et al. proposed CRISPR-Cas12a/Cas13a one-tube detection of SARS-CoV-2 and African Swine fever virus (ASFV) against other coronaviruses and human respiratory viruses. This combination allows for the simultaneous detection of DNA and RNA in a single tube. The author directly recognized one DNA by Cas12 (DNA-guided), while the other DNA was converted into RNA first and the product was recognized by Cas13a (RNA guided). A handheld fluorescence signal reader was connected to a smartphone for signal presentation. The respective presence/absence of target viral genes results in different fluorescence signals, thereby forming a signal heat map for different case analyses [64]. The proposed platform exhibited 100% sensitivity and selectivity for SARS-CoV-2 and ASFV clinical sample detection. Combining CRISPR-Cas12a/Cas13a systems also resulted in higher detection accuracy and one-time detection throughput. However, dependence on preamplification limits the flexibility of the diagnostic approach.

For label-free codex RI biosensors, the performance depends not only on high quality factor transducer design, but also on the amount of property change (codex RI/biolayer thickness change) that the bioreaction can bring to the matrices. Therefore, signal amplification strategies are urgently required. In our recent work, a horseradish peroxidase and 3,3′- diaminobenzidine reaction was introduced to generate precipitates on the tip of an optical fiber. This increases the biolayer thickness and optical signals by more than 100-fold [66].

There is still scope for innovation in optical multi-virus biosensors. First, as extraordinary progress has been made in RI sensors, to further improve sensitivity, the interaction between virus/bio-events (such as antibody-virus binding) and light, as well as their effect on transducer properties should be deeply studied at a single biomolecule and photon scale, where the quantum effect must be considered, and continuous or real-time measurement can disturb the system. Therefore, quantum non-demolition measurement can be a promising approach, where perturbation is confined to the conjugate parameter [67,68].

Second, the performance of optical evanescent wave biosensing is limited by the weak electromagnetic field tail at the bio-interface [69,70]. Therefore, a high-Q-factor transducer design with a smaller sensing volume and stronger electromagnetic field excited in the bio-layer is expected to be adopted for multi-virus biosensors. In recent studies, whispering gallery mode microcavities with peak EM fields in bio-interfaces have been adopted to overcome this sensitivity [71]. In addition, the compact structure of the microcavities makes it possible for integrated on-chip biosensors, which is expected for future multi-virus biosensors. Another interesting work illustrated that the size of target virus and bio-recognition element can greatly affect the sensitivity for a certain plasmonic metasurface design. This is due to the spatial mismatch between hotspot and the viral particles. This work indicates that to achieve optimal detection performance for different viruses, the meta-structures should be specially designed [29].

Third, in most cases, although the sensor chip is miniaturized owing to advanced nanofabrication technologies, sophisticated instruments (such as the outer light source and optical detector) and precise optical alignments are still required [72]. While the application of microfluidic systems can simplify sensing operations, additional fluidic control devices such as pump and channels are still complexing the platform. Thus, the development of compact optoelectronic multi-virus biosensors with integrated optical paths and devices without losing sensitivity is expected. Alternatively, studies have proposed integrated light sources or optical detectors on-chip to reduce system size [73,74]. Again, a clear relationship between the working structure design, viral properties, and detection performance requires further study. The biosensing system is expected to have a compact and highly integrated structure without affecting the detection performance.

sec.title: Electrochemical biosensors for multi-virus detection
sec.p: An electrochemical biosensor characterizes viruses by detecting electrical signals (e.g., capacitance, current, potential, and conductivity) generated by specific binding [75]. These electrical signals can be the increased impedance or current generated by the oxidation (or reduction) of the electroactive species [76]. This section discusses potentiometric, amperometric, voltammetric, impedimetric, and ECL biosensors for multi-virus detection (Fig. 1).

sec.title: FET-based biosensors
sec.p: An FET biosensor monitors changes in the surface potential when the target molecule binds to the biorecognition element immobilized on a highly conductive chip surface. Nanotechnologies, including integrating nanomaterials and nanostructures, have brought great innovation in transducer design to FET biosensors [77]. Nanomaterial has a high surface-to-volume ratio, and provides extraordinary electrical performance, and greatly enhances antibody immobilization efficiency. Silicon nanowire (SiNW) FETs have been extensively studied for the design of ultrasensitive, label-free, and compact biosensors [78] for detecting multiple influenza viruses [79].

FET-based biosensors can be divided into different channels, regions, and wells for the detection of multiple viruses. Antibodies or aptamers can be immobilized on the corresponding working electrode. A portable FET biosensor that detects different variants of SARS-CoV-2 is shown in Fig. 3 A [80]. The authors constructed separate detection wells on the gate to characterize several synthetic viral variants. Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE-2) and specific antibodies were used as receptors, and the selectivity of the sensor was tested using hemagglutinin from influenza A H1N1. Additionally, FET biosensors can be integrated with microfluidic channels to achieve a high throughput [81]. In this direction, reducing electromagnetic interference is crucial for minimizing the effect of microenvironmental changes on FET performance.

sec.title: Electrochemical amperometric biosensors
sec.p: An electrochemical amperometric biosensor measures the oxidation/reduction current change resulting from the bio-affinity reaction at the electrode surface under a constant working potential [82].

The most commonly used approach for multi-virus sensing in an amperometric biosensor is the working electrode array construction, where the electrodes are functionalized with different bioreceptors to capture the corresponding viral antigens. Based on this, microfluidics were integrated for multichannel sample loading, and a nanostructured sensing surface was adopted to enhance the sensitivity in detecting three influenza viruses simultaneously [83]. The proposed biosensing platform could provide detection result within 1 h, with an LOD of 1 pg mL−1 for each virus.

The enhancement of biosensor flexibility is an emerging topic. Recently, electrochemical paper-based analytical devices (ePAD) have been developed for viral detection. This design enables multiple stages, including sample loading, sensor washing, and detection, to be completed in one step, which significantly simplifies the operation. Boonkaew et al. proposed an ePAD platform for the simultaneous detection of HBsAg and HCVcAg [84]. The samples were added to the inlet region and channeled to the two functionalized working electrodes. The biosensor achieved large linear detection range for HBsAg (0.1–250 ng mL−1) and HCVcAg ((0.001–250 ng mL−1), with only 15 μL samples required for detection. The ePAD sensor was tested using clinical serum samples, and the results were verified using chemiluminescent immunoassay (with ± 2.83% and ± 7.93% relative error).

sec.title: Electrochemical voltammetric biosensors
sec.p: An electrochemical voltammetric biosensor measures the peak current change caused by bio-reactions under various potentials between the two electrodes. Voltammetric techniques include cyclic voltammetry (CV), differential pulse voltammetry (DPV), or square wave voltammetry (SWV).

The adoption of separate working electrodes for multi-virus detection has shown good performance for multiplexed voltammetric biosensor design [85]. Metal nanoparticles can be used as electrode substrates to amplify the response signal by increasing the electron transfer efficiency, thereby improving detection sensitivity [86]. A competitive SWV voltammetric biosensor containing multiple electrode arrays was designed to detect Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) and other coronaviruses [87]; the working mechanism is illustrated in Fig. 3B. The author arranged eight carbon electrodes deposited using Au nanoparticles. The detection was based on indirect competitive binding between in-sample-free MERS-CoV and the immobilized viral antigen to the antibody. Au nanoparticles were used to enhance the electron transfer efficiency and effective electrode surface area, thereby resulting in high sensitivity. When the electrode surface was covered by an antibody, the peak current decreased because the biolayer prevented the ferro/ferricyanide redox couple from approaching the electrode surface, thereby leading to decreased electron transfer efficiency. The biosensor achieved high sensitivity (with an LOD of 1.0 pg mL−1 for MERS-CoV and 0.4 pg mL−1 for HCoV, respectively) and selectivity (no cross-reaction with influenza A and B). In addition, the sensor can be further improved to simultaneously detect hundreds of viruses, as reported previously by authors.

Similarly, the ePAD approach can be adopted to enhance the flexibility of voltammetric biosensors for multiplexed virus detection [88]. A screen-printed carbon electrode on paper substrate immunosensors has recently proven its stability in detecting multiple avian influenza viruses [89]. The biosensor measured the peak current decrease using DPV, achieving 55.7 pg mL−1, 99.6 pg mL−1, and 54.0 pg mL−1 LOD for avian influenza virus (AIV) H5N1, H7N9 and H9N2 hemagglutinin antigens with 20–30 min antibody-antigen binding time and only 10 μL of samples. Furthermore, the biosensor is flexible and easy to manufacture, thereby making it promising for at-home or wearable multi-virus detection.

However, the multiplex detection system described above was performed using multiple separate working electrodes. Moreover, many different approaches suffer from a similar drawback because multiplexed electrochemical detection is performed sequentially, target-by-target, with multiple measuring steps. Recently, the authors described a method based on DPV that simultaneously detected three viruses on a single working electrode [90]. The Au thin film was formed by sputtering onto a micro-hemisphere mold, which was later functionalized with specific antibodies against the three viruses by the self-assembly method. For the multi-virus detection experiment, a single electrode was functionalized with two antibodies at a ratio of 1:1. The sensor was then tested using viral mixtures with the same target concentration, and the DPV response changed with the ratio of the two viruses. The binding efficiency was the highest and the lowest response current peak was observed when the virus ratio reached 1:1. The two viruses were simultaneously detected with a detection limit of around 0.5 ng mL−1 within 2 min. Considering the difference among protein isoelectric points, incubation of different antibodies as a mixture requires stricter control of incubation conditions, such as pH value.

sec.title: Electrochemical impedimetric biosensors
sec.p: Electrochemical impedimetric biosensors measure the capacitance or resistance change caused by receptor-target binding reactions in the sample matrix [91,92]. By applying an AC voltage, the biosensor measures the change in phase or amplitude in response to the impedance change, which is known as electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement [91,93].

Impedimetric biosensors can perform multi-virus detection by constructing multiple separated working electrodes on a single chip followed by the corresponding biofunctionalization. Recently, a portable electrochemical platform for detecting dengue and Zika virus was proposed [94]. The sensor chip contained four Au-deposited, antibody-coated working electrodes (Fig. 3C), and a potentiostat was used to measure the EIS. The biosensor provided a linear relationship between the logarithm of the target concentration and the percentage change in the impedance. Zika and dengue viral proteins was adopted as target elements, achieving 0.54 ng mL−1 and 1.17 ng mL−1 LODs respectively within 10min. The proposed portable device can benefit the POC detection of Zika and Dengue virus and can be extended to detect other viruses by including more electrodes.

sec.title: ECL biosensors
sec.p: Integrating electrochemical and optical signal probes can provide fast response and highly selective detection. ECL sensors convert electrical energy to radiant energy. It transforms the precursors on the electron surface into reactive intermediates, which then form excited states and emit light. These processes involve the transfer of electrons generated by electrochemical reactions and luminescence [95]. ECL can be generated using annihilation and co-reactant approaches. The annihilation ECL platform generates an alternating potential on the electrode with oxidation-reduction electron transfer, thereby forming an excited state and emitting light. Co-reactant species such as oxalate ions can react with ECL luminophores under constant potential to produce an excited state and generate light [95].

An ECL biosensor was proposed to detect the nucleic acid markers of HIV and HPV based on the collateral cleavage activity of CRISPR-Cas12a [96], as shown in Fig. 3D. Au nanoparticles are modified with reporter DNA and probe DNA, where the probe DNA can bind to the end of the HIV DNA that is attached to the sensor chip. HIV DNA was added to the detection system and its front section was linked to the captured DNA on the sensor surface. Thereafter, carbon dot-labeled spherical nucleic acids were added and captured by the unbound section of the HIV DNA. This reaction can be characterized using ECL signals. Subsequently, to further detect HPV-16, the Cas12a/crRNA/HPV-16 dsDNA complex was adapted to “cut” the report DNA, and therefore “turn-off” the illumination. The ECL platform achieved detection limits of 30 fM and 0.32 pM for HIV and HPV- 16 DNAs respectively. Multiplexed detection of the two DNAs was performed in human serum within 2 h, where no extra nucleic acid amplification was required. A similar idea for a switchable “on-off” signal has been used to avoid signal overlapping in multiple miRNA-detecting ECL biosensors [97]. The presence of miRNA-21 “turns-on” the ECL, which is later “turned-off” by the competitive binding of miRNA-155 on locked-DNAzyme.

These studies provide good examples of reducing cross-reactions in multi-virus detection in complicated solutions. When the number of target viruses increases, more chips and reactions are adopted to distinguish the different signals, and logic gates judge the presence of nucleic acid markers.

In electrochemical biosensors, noise from the circuit, bio-interface, and environment can affect the detection performance. Importantly, the electrode surface morphology can significantly affect the detection performance, particularly when adopting a nanostructured surface. Despite their high surface-to-volume ratio, the reproducibility of nanostructured biosensors is impaired because of uncontrollable material defects [98]. In addition, the nanostructure can trap a portion of the viral antigen, which is difficult to remove by washing.

The avoidance of cross-reactions is a concern in electrochemical biosensors. For viral nucleic acid detection, determining the cleavage activity is a good technique for detecting dual targets and guaranteeing detection accuracy [96]. In this case, detection of viral proteins requires initial modification with nucleic acids. In addition, a single-sensor die can detect only a pair of biomarkers. More collateral cleavage molecules should be designed when the number of viral markers multiplies, and a logic gate is required to distinguish different response signals.

Electrochemical measurements deliver nearly real-time results. Therefore, optimizing the incubation time of the sample is the key to shortening the entire duration. Depending on the type of probe, the current incubation time is generally 20–60 min, as shown in Table 3. Moreover, the reaction time for receptor binding on the biochip is too long to be used for POC diagnosis. Thus, optimizing the storage conditions to achieve pre-assay preparation of biochips is important. Additionally, considering that the incubation process is performed under wet conditions, a good design for multi-microfluid channels is necessary to prevent the circuit from being affected by liquids.

sec.title: Mechanical biosensors for multi-virus detection
sec.p: Mechanical biosensors monitor the frequency or mass change before and after virus binding on the working structure and can be categorized into microcantilever (MC), piezoelectric, micropillar, SAW, and photoacoustic types.

sec.title: Microcantilever biosensors
sec.p: MC biosensors contain a microcantilever array in which the probe molecules are immobilized on cantilevers for target analyte detection [76,92]. MC biosensors can be classified as static and dynamic biosensors [92]. The detection mechanism of static MC biosensors is based on surface stress measurement as a consequence of analyte attachment to the microcantilever, where a higher sensitivity was recorded using long and highly flexible cantilevers. In contrast, dynamic MC biosensors monitor the resonant frequency shift; therefore, their performance can be improved using short and stiff cantilevers [99].

Multi-virus detection based on a dynamic MC biosensor was performed through sensor array construction and immobilization of different receptors on separated cantilevers or different regions on one cantilever. A model of an MC biosensor for multi-virus detection was proposed to distinguish different targets by measuring the maximum resonance frequency shift [100]. The simulated model can recognize biomolecules and distinguish their dimensional information by measuring the voltage applied, which causes beam instability. In another study, an optical micro-electromechanical system (MEMS) cantilever biosensor was proposed to label-freely detect hepatitis A and hepatitis C viral antigens [101]. The electroplated Ni MCs contain diffraction gratings for interferometric sensing. The resonance frequency was monitored using a control circuit and frequency counter. Specific antibodies were used to functionalize the cantilevers of the two biosensors. The sensor contained 4000 cantilevers, and the reference and detection surfaces were placed on the same die to avoid the vibration effect from the ambient environment; a detection limit of 0.1 ng mL−1 was achieved with a dynamic range of more than 1000 for both viral antigens.

As MC biosensors recognize targets by resonance frequency/mass analysis, they cannot be used when the particle sizes or substances are unclear [100]. In addition, the viral particle dimensions should be considered when determining the electrode critical deflection.

sec.title: Piezoelectric biosensors
sec.p: Piezoelectric materials such as AlN, ZnO, and BaTiO3 exhibit mechanical oscillations when an AC voltage is applied. The target antigen interacts with an adequately immobilized probe molecule in the sensing area of the piezoelectric biosensor [102], thereby increasing the mass and leading to a decrease in the corresponding oscillation frequency compared with that during the antigen-free state [103,104].

In this context, Bisoffi et al. developed an easily operated and portable surface acoustic wave biosensor for the detection of multiple biomarkers in complex fluids [105]. The chip was fabricated using the conventional lithographic deposition and patterning of interdigital transducers and silica waveguide layers on an interdigital transducer wafer. Two channels were functionalized with specific antibodies against HIV-1 and HIV-2, whereas isotype control antibodies were immobilized on the other two channels. The authors verified the performance of the proposed platform using a defined buffer and human serum. As a result, all the virus measurements took 5 min with an LOD of 12 TCID50s and 87 TCID50s for HIV-1 and HIV-2 in the defined buffer, respectively.

sec.title: Advantages and challenges of mechanical multi-virus detection
sec.p:
Table 4 summarizes the impressive mechanical biosensors used for multi-virus detection. Generally, the performance of MC biosensors for multi-virus detection still depends on various factors such as antigen distribution, surface energy, and ambient environment. The antibodies are expected to be uniformly immobilized on a single side of the cantilever. Different antibodies should be precisely bound to the designed cantilevers (or regions on the cantilever) to avoid cross-reactions when used for multitarget detection. In addition, an MC biosensor can exhibit various resonant mode shapes, including lateral, bending, and torsional modes [76]. Although the bending mode is most commonly used for sensor design, it is extremely important to investigate the effect of different resonant modes on multi-virus detection, as the viral particle sizes also affect the MC biosensor performance. In addition, the need for a multichannel frequency detector complicates device design. In this respect, piezoelectric biosensors that do not rely on frequency shift analysis are desirable.

sec.title: Surface functionalization for multi-virus biosensors
sec.p: Proper design of the bio-interface has a significant effect on the sensitivity, accuracy, and selectivity of biosensors. There are four main immobilization techniques for optimal biosensing: absorption, covalent bonding [107,108], affinity immobilization [109,110], and molecular imprinting [111].

When adopting a protein as a receptor, optimal performance requires proteins to be immobilized on a surface in an oriented form rather than a random form [112]. Two strategies can realize oriented binding. The first is the oriented covalent binding. This occurs when the protein is modified with active groups such as thiol groups, which may damage the protein. In this case, an extra group, such as a carbohydrate group [113] or enzyme recognition tag [114], is usually attached to the protein surface for protection. The second method is affinity immobilization. This occurs when applying high-affinity biomolecules, including short peptides (such as an HIS tag-modified antibody), small proteins, and nucleic acids, to react with the proteins coated on the sensor surface.

As mentioned previously, reducing the incubation time of sensing elements is an important factor to consider. The dependence on multiple steps, various reagents, and repeated washing also blocks the detection efficiency and highlights the importance of fully automated devices.

In general, the required immobilization chemistry becomes more complex for the development of a multiplexed virus biosensor, thereby necessitating the immobilization of multiple complementary oligonucleotide probes for different individual virus targets on the surface of multiple or single detection units. Multiple ROIs can result in higher signal selectivity, particularly when the sample amount increases. All-in-one detection provides a one-step operation; however, it requires precisely designed incubation conditions and advanced techniques to avoid signal overlapping.

sec.title: Progress, challenges, and future perspectives
sec.p: Multi-virus biosensing technology has made tremendous progress in recent years. The precise design of transducers, state-of-the-art nanofabrication, and bio-interface innovation have improved the sensitivity, accuracy, and selectivity of multi-virus biosensors. In addition, the amount of sample for detection has been minimized from the picoliter to the microliter scale, while advancements in artificial intelligence make the prediction of viral species possible [25].

RI optical biosensors are versatile and suitable for various applications. They provide label-free and fast detection and are less vulnerable to electrochemical interference and liquid environments. Imaging devices enable optical biosensors to reach thousands of throughputs. In contrast, electrochemical biosensors can be designed to be more flexible and can suit various mobile, wireless, or wearable devices. In addition, more portable/handheld platforms have been reported for electrochemical multiplexed biosensors, thereby satisfying the POC applications. Independent working electrodes and multichannel detection schemes can minimize cross infections among different targets. Mechanical biosensors provide high sensitivity and can be integrated with other platforms to achieve an important detection limit [67]. However, mechanical biosensors have brittle structures and are more sensitive to environmental interference.
In the following sections, we will discuss multiplexed sensing strategies, challenges in the matrix environment and real applications, and future perspectives for multi-virus biosensing platforms.

sec.title: Progress: multi-virus detection strategies
sec.p: The basic multiplexed biosensing strategies of the three platforms can be categorized into multichannel devices with independent sensor units, micro-ROI on-chip construction, and label-based all-in-one detection.

First, one platform composed of multiple biosensors has the highest commercialization level, where each die or well detects a particular virus. The independent detection units miniaturize cross-infection, and multiplexed detection is achieved using a multichannel apparatus. Currently, commercialized multi-channel detection platforms such as the Fortebio [38] and multichannel electrochemical workstations are available. However, these platforms can only detect several targets simultaneously because of their limited scanning speed and channel amount/space [24,115]. With more sensor chips involved, the detection time, dimension, and complexity of the instruments will also increase [116].

Second, constructing micro-ROI arrays on a single chip is a popular research topic. Each working ROI is functionalized with a specific receptor that can be printed on a chip using commercial instruments [17,19,45]. The throughput has dramatically increased to thousands owing to booming imaging devices [19]. Advances in lab-on-chip, lab-on-fiber, and optoelectronic techniques have significantly increased the integration level of biosensors. Therefore, the requirement for nanotechnology increases the cost of sensor fabrication. Avoiding cross-reactions and signal overlap between different detection regions is also strictly required.

Third, all-in-one detection is emerging in label-based biosensors, where targets are distinguished by specific signal labels and simultaneous detection is achieved within one reaction system (such as one-tube sensing). The main concerns here include avoiding cross-reactions in one matrix and simplifying the bio-reaction steps or series. In addition, to generate distinguishable signals, throughput is limited when performing parallel detection.

sec.title: Matrices environment for multi-virus detection
sec.p: To date, nearly all virus biosensing has been carried out in liquid samples, where a continuous flowing solution, liquid switching, and unbound molecules can bring noise [115,117]. For electrochemical biosensors, precise packaging is required to prevent corrosion and electrical shortages. For mechanical biosensors, large liquid damping affects the detection performance [118]. One way to reduce this is to limit the sample amount to the picogram level [119], which may increase the analysis time and limit its use for on-site POC analysis.

Biosensing in gas matrices, such as exhaled breath and air, is attractive [120], especially for airborne virus detection and health monitoring. One of the main concerns for gas diagnosis is the low target concentration. Previous researchers [121] concluded that versatile metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a porous material with metal nodes, and organic linkers showed good performance in sensing various COVID-19 markers and have the potential for exhaled breath analysis. A more recent biosensing platform was introduced to detect SARS-CoV-2 particles in exhaled breath [122]. The 22 mm square impactor trapped more than 85% of micro-/macro-particles in exhaled breath, and the RNA amount satisfied the PCR requirement within 1 min for detection. In addition, a reusable biosensor that monitors SARS-CoV-2 in real-time with an LOD of 60 copies mL−1 in swabs and exhaled breath condensates was described [123]. The quasi-freestanding epitaxial graphene sensor measured the Raman shift and voltage fractional shift to detect the target virus. Impressively, the sensor can characterize the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein down to 1 ag mL−1. These studies provide guidance for device design to detect multiple viruses in non-liquid environments by altering the bio-interface design. As more bio-reactions occur in the liquid matrix, there is still a long way to go before sensitive real-time virus sensing in gas can be commercialized.

sec.title: Future perspectives for multi-virus detection
sec.p: In this section, we discuss integrated multiplexed biosensing systems that can achieve extraordinary performance in terms of sensitivity or integration level and have the potential to benefit future multi-virus biosensing platforms.

sec.title: Optoelectronic multiplexed sensing
sec.p:
Optical and electrochemical biosensors have achieved impressive sensitivity in virus sensing. However, their sensitivity is limited by the inherent 1/f low-frequency noise originating from material/circuit carrier instability [124,125]. Recently, an integrated waveguide-based biosensor was proposed for HIV-1-like particle detection. The detection limit reaches the atto-gram level, thereby surpassing 1/f noise by adopting an integrated heterodyne interferometer and up-conversion amplification [125]. The integrated waveguide arrays performed radio frequency (RF) multiplexed sensing, where the incidence was shifted by RFs into multiple waveguides, as illustrated in Fig. 4 A(a). The authors concluded that the capture efficiency was enhanced based on the proposed circuit configuration and verified the single HIV-like nanoparticle-sensing ability of the aerosol. The response signals after the virus-like particles were trapped in the sensor are illustrated in Fig. 4A(b). sec.title: Optomechanical multiplexed sensing
sec.p: The quantum effect should be considered for biosensing on a single viral particle scale as the system state is disturbed owing to continuous monitoring. Therefore, quantum non-demolition (QND) measurement was proposed for measuring the conjugate variable to characterize the target variable [126]. Therefore, a combination of different sensing systems enables the measurement of one parameter from other systems [127]. One study monitored a moving micromirror to characterize light intensity vibration. The setup of the proposed QND system is illustrated in Fig. 4B(a) [67]. The QND measurement monitors two quadratures of the quantum signal, including the meter parameter (Ym) and signal parameter (Xs), and tests their perfect correlations. For the experiment, an oscillator micro-mirror with a specially designed structure (Fig. 4B(b)) achieved minimum internal deformation under vertical displacement. As a result, both the signal field and residual fluctuation spectrum density fall below the standard quantum level, as illustrated in Fig. 4B(c). The system provides a good approach to achieving sub-standard quantum-level noise for single-virus detection, which is elusive in classical measurements.

sec.title: Future perspectives
sec.p: Currently, multiplexed detection largely relies on the repetition of detection units and different receptors, which enhances throughput but lacks a targeted design for a specific virus. For example, respiratory viruses have different properties (such as viral particle sizes ranging from 60 to 250 nm) [128], and one transducer design may not be suitable for all types of viral antigens. This is especially important for structure-based biosensors such as optical metamaterial biosensors and mechanical biosensors, where the spatial matching between different viral targets and the working structure can greatly affect the sensitivity. Therefore, “detection of a specific virus” can be a good topic for future studies. Furthermore, tracking virus evolution and preparing for an upcoming viral disease is of great importance and requires cooperation from different research fields.

Large and complex instrumentation is always a main concern in the development of portable and compact biosensing platforms, especially for at-home, POC, and real-time healthcare applications. To date, a wireless, small, and portable electrochemical platform integrated with a mobile phone has been proposed, with multiple channels for simultaneous analyte detection [129]. A handheld platform with an assembled light source, sensor kit, and CMOS camera [130] has also been reported for POC H1N1 detection. These advancements are expected to be adopted for multi-virus biosensing in the near future.

Collectively, multiple viruses from human, food, and environmental samples can be detected using a smart system, as shown in Fig. 5 . On-chip detection units coupled with microfluidic channels can detect multiple viruses with a high throughput. The new-generation system will be able to distinguish newly emerging and unknown viruses from existing ones. Multi-virus detection will be performed on-site together with a user-friendly graphical interface for POC or at-home diagnosis to display each sample result in real-time via a smart app.Fig. 5
Future perspectives for the design of a smart system for multi-virus biosensing. A smart device is expected to be compact and flexible for multi-virus biosensing using the parallel detection units constructed on one transducer. Viruses can be collected in various formats and from various scenarios such as public environment, food and human body. A smart phone will be connected to the sensor kit to control the entire detection process and later, to visualize results in just seconds. Each ROI is specially designed to achieve its optimal detection performance in respect to accuracy, specificity, and sensitivity for a given virus.Fig. 5

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This paper reviews optical, electrochemical, and mechanical multi-virus detection platforms, including their mechanisms, multiplexed sensing, and biofunctionalization strategies. Compared to single-virus biosensing, multi-virus biosensing should achieve not only high sensitivity, accuracy, and selectivity, but also address the particular challenges faced from multiple perspectives before taking steps towards clinical applications. From the perspective of the platform, real-time monitoring of healthcare and POC testing are expected. While multi-channel detectors have matured, commercialization of multifunctional microsensor chips still requires further development in device integration/miniaturization and microfluidic systems. From the perspective of the transducer, the ability of a single virus or viral “fingerprint” analysis for early stage diagnosis and virus evolution tracking is of interest for future studies. From the perspective of the bio-interface, avoiding cross-interactions and shortening the incubation time are urgent.

Multi-virus biosensing platforms are intended to protect public health. They can be applied in viral coinfection diagnosis, highly infectious viral disease control, vaccines, and medicine development. Thus, this review aims to provide design guidance for future and existing multi-virus biosensing platforms.

bio.p: Yuqiao Zheng is a joint Ph.D. student at Center of Excellence in Biomedical Research on Advances-on-Chips Neurotechnologies (CenBRAIN Neurotech) at School of Engineering, Westlake University (Hangzhou, China) and Zhejiang University (Hangzhou, China). She received her master's degree in the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Hong Kong, China) and bachelor's degree in Xi'an Jiaotong University (Xi'an China). She has authored three articles in peer-reviewed journals in field of biosensors. She received six awards during her educational endeavors, including five scholarships and one excellent student. Yuqiao Zheng is interested in optical biosensors, nanotechnologies, and their application in virus detection.

Xixi Song is a research assistant at CenBRAIN Neurotech, School of Engineering, Westlake University (Hangzhou, China). She holds a bachelor's degree in biotechnology from Shihezi University (Shihezi, China), and master's degree in biochemistry and molecular biology from Chinese Academy of Forestry (Beijing, China). She has authored three articles in peer-reviewed journals. She is now interested in biointerface design for lab-on-chip biosensors to achieve high detection performance.

Zina Fredj is a Postdoctoral Researcher at CenBRAIN Neurotech, School of Engineering, Westlake University. Her research interests include new nanostructured electrode materials and modified electrode surfaces, electrochemical sensors and biosensors, and their applications in the environmental, and biomedical areas. She received her PhD degree in Physics engineering in 2019 from the Higher School of Science and Technology, University of Sousse, Tunisia. Then she occupied a one-year postdoctoral position focused on the development of nanobioplatforms for the diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 at the Research center of microelectronics and nanotechnology, Tunisia. She has published/presented over 18 papers/communications in the area of biosensors.

Sumin Bian is a Research Assistant Professor at CenBRAIN Neurotech, School of Engineering, Westlake University, with multidisciplinary research interests in biosensor integrated organoids-on-chips for precision medicine applications. Dr. Bian received the Ph.D. degree in Pharmaceutical Science from Katholieke Universiteit Leuven (Leuven, Belgium) in 2018, and the M.Eng. in Nutrition and Food Safety from China Agricultural University (Beijing, China) in 2014. She was awarded multiple Chinese National Scholarships in recognition of her passionate pursuit of science during her educational endeavors. She has authored over 25 Science Citation Index listed papers in journals including Biosensors & Bioelectronics, Journal of Pharmaceutical Analysis, and Inflammatory Bowel Diseases, and holds four national innovation patents. She serves as a Youth Editor of The Innovation- Cell Press, the Review Editor of the Frontiers in Analytical Science Journal and as an invited reviewer for many other international journals. In 2022, she was awarded a Youth Science Fund grant from the National Natural Science Foundation of China.

Mohamad Sawan is a Chair Professor in Westlake University (Hangzhou, China). He is the founder and director of CenBRAIN Neurotech Center of Excellence, Westlake University. He is also an Emeritus Professor in Polytechnique Montréal, Canada. He published more than 1000 peer-reviewed papers, one Handbook, three books, 13 book chapters, 12 patents, and 20 other patents are pending. He received several awards, among them the most prestigious and first Polytechnique Montreal Research and Innovation Award, the J.A. Bombardier and Jacques-Rousseau Awards from the ACFAS, the Queen Elizabeth II Golden Jubilee Medal, the Medal of Merit from the President of Lebanon, the Barbara Turnbull Award from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR), the Shanghai International Collaboration Award, the Zhejiang Westlake Friendship Award, and the Qianjiang Friendship Ambassador Award. Dr. Sawan is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Canada, a Fellow of the Canadian Academy of Engineering, a Fellow of the Engineering Institutes of Canada, a Fellow of the IEEE, a Fellow of the Asia-Pacific Artificial Intelligence Association (AAIA), and an “Officer” of the National Order of Quebec.
